ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained further understanding of the Chinese language, including grammar, vocabulary, and tones. I also gained insight into Chinese culture.
I definitely got more confident in my Chinese grammar, but that was definitely supplemented by the outside work I did with a CLS tutor.
I learned a lot of Chinese grammar and new vocabulary through taking this course.
I gained more vocabulary and grammar, as well as practice more in perfecting my tones.
Zhang Laoshi is very knowledgable and added meaningful cultural and linguistic background, along with tips on what to focus on that were very helpful.
Chinese
I learned a lot about Chinese in this course. I was able to further my knowledge of not just the language but the Chinese culture as well.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
STRENGTHS: Information is well-organized, instructors are incredibly helpful, workload is manageable, content is interesting

WEAKNESSES: n/a
The online homework seemed to be graded arbitrarily and rather strictly

Strength: awesome teacher and TA
Weakness: Mandarin is hard. The book is outdated in some vocabs, and I feel like what I am learning is not really what a daily conversation would look like. The book feels very formal.
Great course

I think a strength of this course was the professor. I think he kept everyone in the class engaged and on their toes and interested. He was very open and welcoming and not intimidating at all which made me feel comfortable, especially since this is a language course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The best practice is the everyday meetings with the class. The class bonded more, and the everyday meetings allow the materials to be retained for a longer period.
Language classes are always harder online, but it worked.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! The Chinese department at Yale is incredible and all the instructors are so nice. There is definitely a lot of support to help facilitate learning. You will learn a lot, especially if you put the time in.

take this class, but be mindful that language study (like anything, I suppose) really is what you put into it.  That being said, take the course, meet with your teacher, and get a tutor through the CLS and you'll see your Chinese grow EXPONENTIALLY.

I would recommend this course to any student interested in learning Chinese. Since the course meets everyday, it is quite intensive but you do end up learning a lot of Chinese in a relatively fun environment. The course is organized well and the Chinese department at Yale is very welcoming.
Yes, if you're interested in learning Mandarin and are willing to put in the hard work. It's such a cool language and once you master it, Korean and Japanese can become easier to learn.
If they're interested in Chinese, yes. But it's a lot of work.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: live virtual tutorial sessions with a Chinese graduate student.
Weekly section with TF
A virtual, interactive language class, with exercises
One-on-one tutorial
